NEWS BITES

U.K.’s Build-to-Rent Sector Experiences a Boom This Year The U.K. has 148,046 build-to-rent homes that were either already completed or are in planning this year, which is a 20% year-over-year increase, according to the British Property Federation and Savills. Completed units have also risen year-over-year by 31%, with the most growth occurring in the third quarter. PropertyWire

California’s Sales Flatlined in September California home sales remained flat month-over-month in September with 404,030 units sold even though year-over-year sales rose for the third straight year, according to the California Association of Realtors. Sales were down 0.5% from August with 406,100 sales, but were up by 5.8% from September 2018. World Property Journal

Large Co-Living Properties in Hong Kong Grow in Popularity Co-living operators in Hong Kong are rushing to increase the supply of units as popularity among renters who have their own room but share common areas grows. There are currently 400 large co-living units in Hong Kong and operators plan to add another 1,400 units by the end of 2020, according to Barry Chung, a senior associate director at Savills Hong Kong. Prices per unit range from HK$7,000 (US$892) to HK$22,000 per month. South China Morning Post

Trump Tower Builder in India Shifts Focus Away From Luxury Homes Macrotech Developers, a Trump Tower developer in Mumbai, India, has changed direction toward cheaper apartments after a credit squeeze stifles demand for luxury properties. The company’s luxury housing portfolio is being cut by 17% to 30% and increasing contributions to affordable housing by 50%, according to managing director Abhishek Lodha. Business Times

Canadian Election May Result in New Taxes for Foreign Buyers Both the Liberals and the New Democrats in Canada support new taxes on foreign homebuyers and homeowners. Newly re-elected Prime Minister Justin Trudeau promised to create a national tax on vacant homes owned by foreigners. The Liberals plan to model the tax off of a similar policy in British Columbia. Vancouver Sun
